title.narrative: Consultancy Support to CSO Development in Ukraine
Konsultstöd till utveckling av civilsamhällesorganisationer i Ukraina

description.narrative: Ambassaden i Ukraina planerar att fortsätta stödja civilsamhällesorganisationer (CSO:er) för att de ska bli hållbara, ha stark ledning och kapacitet att främja förändringar och reformer i Ukraina. Det tidigare konsultkontraktet har löpt ut, och ambassaden i Kiev skulle vilja upphandla en ny konsult med särskild expertis inom institutionell utveckling av CSO:er.

The Embassy in Ukraine is keen to continue to support civil society organisations (CSOs) to become sustainable, well-managed and capacitated to promote changes and reforms in Ukraine. The previous consultancy contract has expired and the Embassy in Kyiv would like to procure a new consultancy with a special expertise in organizational/institutional development area of CSOs.

title.narrative: Decision on Contribution Consultancy Support to CSO Development in Ukraine
Contract with the Nordic Consulting Group on Consultancy Support to CSO Development in Ukraine

description.narrative:
The overall approach of the assignment as explained in NCGs original proposal and is premised on:
1) an organisational development model, based on Results-Based Management (RBM), focusing on how the CSOs aim to improve their capacity and seek to increase the effects and impact of their interventions, and
2) a Human Rights Based Approach (HRBA) as fundamental guiding principle of any assistance to the CSOs (technical support, on-distance advice and feedback, and training), as well as on how the CSOs apply HRBA in their own work.
So far, the support has included a number of audits, various forms of assessments including an online survey of the CSOs knowledge and capacity to apply gender equality and mainstreaming, RBM, HRBA, conflict, environment, and integrity mechanisms in their work.
Further, an individual technical support has been provided to the CSOs. The present report focuses on audits, training courses, governance seminars, and individual technical support.
Currently, Sida is collaborating with 16 CSOs. A strong point of departure for the CSO Systems Help project is conducting SBAs and VAs (follow-up audits) of CSOs, at the Embassy's request.
The audits provide a substantial foundation for defining organisational needs and areas for improvement and recommendations are therefore useful as point of departure for development of capacity development action plans.
It has been a priority for the team to conduct as many audits as possible from the outset of the assignment and fortunately, the team was able to conduct one audit already in December 2019, eight audits in 2020, and one audit in the early months of 2021. In total ten SBAs/VAs have therefore been conducted since the start of the assignment.
Overall, seven out of ten audits system-based and verifications ones have been conducted online, with some of them being still in a hybrid form (where national experts could and chose to conduct face-to-face visits).
In April-Maj 2020, staff and management surveys were implemented with the CSOs.
The intention of the surveys was to identify strengths and weaknesses in the CSOs ability to comply with Sidas requirements, perspectives, and priorities on gender equality and mainstreaming, RBM, strategic planning, HRBA, environment, conflict and integrity and anti-corruption measures.
Most of the CSOs, have developed draft action plans in 2020, with organisational priorities.
The current assignment emphasises engagement with the boards and upholding good democratic governance standards. As part of starting up this focus area, experts form the NCG team in December 2020 developed a curriculum for a learning process for management and boards. As a result, 3 separate sessions have been held for all CEOs and board members of partner organizations.
During Q3-Q4 2020 three learning processes in a. Conflict with a gender perspective, b. Environment, and c. RBM were implemented.
In October and November, three online modules on Conflict with a Gender perspective including a session for management were conducted. This included bilateral sparring for the CSOs in between the online modules.
Moreover, two RBM online modules were implemented in November 2020 also with individual learning sessions for the CSOs in between. As for the learning process on Environment, the first online session took place in mid-December 2020 and the second in end of January 2021.
The CSOs were invited to request individual learning sessions to help them anchor new (or updated knowledge). A few CSOs has seized the opportunity and NCG organized individual coach support.
